PREVENTION PROGRAM DATA

AWTP is a municipal water treatment facility.  This facility falls under the NAICS code 22131.  Our safety information was last reviewed and updated May 14, 2004.  We are subject to the handling codes of the National Fire Protection Association for Compressed Gas Cylinder Storage, American National Standards Institute, and American Society of Mechanical Engineers standards.  These standards, and all applicable OSHA standards (though not required) have been implemented here through written manuals by Environmental Data Services, Inc.  The most recent hazard review and update was conducted for this facility on May 17, 2004. To prevent/limit releases, this facility uses an automatic shutoff vacuum system, manual valve shutoffs, and pressure regulators.  Due to the type and quantity of hazardous materials handled at this facility and a large number of offsite receptors, this facility incorporates a mitigation system which includes the vacuum system, and concrete block wall enclosure to limit the amount of release.  The facility also uses detection devices such as a chlorine alarm, which indicates a release with a visual and audible alarm. Operating and training procedures were also reviewed and revised on May 14, 2004.  The employees of AWTP are trained in the classroom and by on-the-job training.  This training is completed with competency tests including demonstration and observation.  The maintenance procedures are reviewed by operators regularly to ensure proper chlorine cylinder change-out.  The last time they were reviewed and written out was on May 14, 2004. There have been no incident investigations the past five years. The June 2004 update and resubmission of the RMP triggered a review of our safety information, operating and maintenance procedures and training.  

AWTP is a Level 2 Prevention Program facility, yet chooses to utilize a Level 3 PSM Prevention Program to further emphasize its role in the protection of the environment and surrounding community.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

In this water treatment plant facility, we handle chlorine with is considered hazardous by EPA.  The same properties that makes chlorine valuable as a water treatment chemical, also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling chlorine. Overall, the prevention of unnecessary human exposure, reducing the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-worker, and reducing the threat to nearby members of the community is the main goal of incorporating this risk management plan into our daily operations.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, with the safe handling procedures that we utilize, and the training of our personnel.  

Our emergency response program was developed with the assistance of Environmental Data Services, Inc.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the Pottsville Fire Department, then the notification of Terry Gardner (Plant Manager), and then notifying the Pope County 911 System for 911 call-out to responding agencies.  The Pottsville Fire Department and Pottsville Police Department will help to notify and evacuate any potentially affected neighbors by utilizing vehicles with PA mounted announcing systems.  The 911 System will also notify Pope County Office of Emergency Management.  

The primary purpose of this facility is to treat the water system by utilizing chemicals such as chlorine. Chlorine is received by individual one ton cylinders at the Galla Park Rd. location and stored until needed. Chlorine is fed into the water system by automatic feeders.  All cylinders operate on a vacuum system. This vacuum system will prevent the continual operation of the system if there is an increase or decrease in operating pressure on the cylinders or lines.  Access to the site is restricted to authoriz

ed facility employees, authorized management personnel, and authorized contractors.  

The regulated substance handled at the Galla Park Rd. location is chlorine.  The maximum amount of chlorine that can be stored at this plant is 6,000 pounds.  There will only be one cylinder (2,000 pounds) on line at any one time, and one on automatic switch-over.  The rest of the 2,000 pounds are in storage.


 
The worst-case scenario is failure of my largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed would release 2,000 pounds of chlorine from the Galla Park Rd. location. Passive mitigation has been considered for this scenario.  The chlorine storage tanks are located in the chlorine feed room which is constructed of concrete walls on all sides with contact with outside air.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor.  The distance to the endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l for the worst-case scenario is 0.9 miles.  This location is classified as urban due to the thickly populated trees and steep hilly terrain around the site.  Within this affected area, there are approximately 208 persons, and 81 households.  The population densities were determined using Landview 5 Software published by the US Census Bureau and EPA.

An alternative scenario was determined for this facility; however, based on the type of prevention system in place, the alternative release from a one ton cylinder should be minimal for the Galla Park Rd. site.  The vacuum system has been determined to be effective in preventing small amounts of chlorine from escaping upon a system failure.  An estimation, based on the line capacity for the feeder lines, would be approximately 10 pounds released into the atmosphere.  This amount of vapor chlorine release would result in a distance to endpoint of approximately <0.1 miles.  Within this affected area, there are approximately 0 persons,and 0 households.  The population densities were determined using Landview 5 Software published by the US Census

Bureau and EPA.

This water treatment facility complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. 

We have had no accidental releases of chlorine in the last five years.  The automatic vacuum system limits the amount (if any) of chlorine that escapes during operational periods.

Our emergency response program was developed with the assistance of Environmental Data Services, Inc.  We have discussed this program with the Pope County Office of Emergency Management (Dewey Traylor (479)-968-1800), the Pope County 911 System, the Pope County Sheriff?s Office, as well as the Pottsville Fire Department (HazMat Response Agency). A representative of Environmental Data Services, Inc. visited this plant October 24, 2002.

The water treatment facility at the Galla Park Rd. facility was constructed in 1976, and the one-ton chlorination system was added in 1995.  This facility is in compliance with all applicable regulations for water treatment facilities.
